statement:
**Theorem** Let $\mathcal{H}$ be a separable Hilbert space and let
$T \in L(\mathcal{H})$. Then $T$ is a compact operator iff there is a
sequence $\{F_n\}$ of finite rank operators with $\|T - F_n\| \to 0$.

$(\Rightarrow)$: Assume $T$ is compact on $\mathcal{H}$ and $\{e_n\}$ is
an orthonormal basis of $\mathcal{H}$. Define: $$\begin{aligned}
P_n f &= \sum_{k=0}^n {\langle f, e_k \rangle} e_k \end{aligned}$$

It is clear that the $P_n$ have finite rank and that we have
$\Vert P_n f\Vert \leq \Vert f\Vert$ for all $n \in \mathbb{N}$,
$f \in \mathcal{H}$.

Let $\mathcal{B}$ be the unit ball in $\mathcal{H}$. We have that
$P_n \to I$ pointwise. Since the $P_n$ are contractive they are
equicontinuous, hence $P_n$ converges uniformly to $I$ on compact sets,
and in particular on $ \overline{T(\mathcal{B})}$, which is compact by
assumption. Therefore $P_n T \to T$ uniformly on $\mathcal{B}$, hence
$\|P_n T - T\| \to 0$. Since $P_n T$ is bounded and of finite rank the
first direction follows.

$(\Leftarrow)$: Now let $\{F_n\}$ be a sequence of bounded operators of
finite rank with $\|T - F_n\| \to 0$. We have to show that
$T(\mathcal{B})$ is relatively compact in $\mathcal{H}$. This is
equivalent to $T(\mathcal{B})$ being totally bounded in $\mathcal{H}$.
So we are left to show that for all $\epsilon > 0$ there is an
$\epsilon$-net $x_1, \cdots, x_n \in \mathcal{H}$ so that:
$$\begin{aligned}
T(\mathcal{B}) &\subseteq \bigcup_{k=1}^n B_{\epsilon}(x_k)\end{aligned}$$

So choose $\epsilon > 0$ and $n \in \mathbb{N}$ fixed so that:
$$\|F_n - T\| < \frac{\epsilon}{2}$$

Choose $x_1, \cdots, x_m \in \mathcal{H}$ with: $$\begin{aligned}
F_n(\mathcal{B}) &\subseteq \bigcup_{k=1}^m B_{\frac{\epsilon}{2}}(x_k)\end{aligned}$$

Hence (by the triangle inequality): $$\begin{aligned}
T(\mathcal{B}) &\subseteq \bigcup_{k=1}^m B_{\epsilon}(x_k)\end{aligned}$$

and we are done.
names: finite rank approximation on separable Hilbert spaces
